awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikuran convergent margin
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikurangi convergent margin

The physical processes dictating the spectrum of fault slip modes (spanning destructive earthquakes to slow slip events and aseismic creep) and the links between these behaviors and long-term morphotectonic evolution of subduction systems are not understood. There is a fundamental need to address this important problem with an integrated, system-level approach combining geodynamical modeling with high-quality geophysical and geological constraints on subduction margin characteristics.

This project will conduct an interdisciplinary, multinational collaborative program involving the USA, New Zealand, Japan and the UK to evaluate system-level controls on processes that govern both slip behavior and long-term deformation at subduction zones. The focus is on the Hikurangi margin in New Zealand, where GPS data show a transition in slip behavior from predominantly stick-slip in the south to aseismic creep in the northern North Island, and where a wide range of subduction-related processes and characteristics vary along-strike. The aim is to rigorously investigate the feedbacks between plate interface slip behavior, solid and fluid mass fluxes, and manifestations of plate boundary mechanics in the long-term geological record that likely reflect common driving processes linking forearc uplift, sediment transfer and underplating, plate boundary strength, and seismogenesis. The Principal Investigators will address this important problem through an integrated approach combining large-scale seismic imaging, paleoseismology, and geomorphology, focused through the lens of state-of-the-art numerical modelling.

por.por_cntn:
North Island, New Zealand has historically hosted large magnitude earthquakes. The setting which causes these earthquakes is similar to the setting of the magnitude 9 earthquake in Japan in 2011, and generally similar to the setting in the Pacific Northwest. In North Island, the Pacific plate subducts beneath the Australian plate at a rate of about 42 mm per year. The friction on the boundary between these two plates builds up stress which is released during an earthquake. Because the boundary is near the surface, the potential for seismic waves created by an earthquake are more likely to be felt at the surface and, if the waves are strong enough, can damage buildings in Auckland and other cities across New Zealand. Additionally, because of the movement created by an earthquake, landslides and tsunamis are also major hazards in settings like this.

This NSF project was part of an international collaboration with New Zealand and Japanese scientists to image the geometry, depth, and structure of the Australian and Pacific plates beneath North Island. The project focused on the Raukumara Peninsula and surrounding region of North Island, where 900 seismometer sites collected data. Seismology methods used seismic waves created by five 500 kg underground explosions and numerous earthquakes to produce what is essentially a CAT scan of the earth. This scan identified the structure and composition of the Australian and Pacific plates. These results can help scientists understand where and why large earthquakes occur and can help them estimate hazards for New Zealand. This NSF project provided overseas field experience for US graduate students, who also had the opportunity to meet and collaborate with scientists and other graduate students from New Zealand.
